Core Course: Tracer Evaluation Report The Water Policy Reform Program of the Economic Development Institute*
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Mark D. Bardini Advisor Evaluation Specialist (202) 458-5625 (202) 458-1572
Number 4 April 1998
Patorni, Francois-Marie (*Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
A tracer evaluation was undertaken by the Evaluation Unit of EDI on the Water Reform Policy Program (WPRP). Specifically, participants were surveyed from sixteen WPRP activities that were conducted by EDI in various countries throughout the world between 1993 and 1997. The primary source of evaluative data was from a questionnaire that was mailed to one hundred high-level participants in various countries who had attended these programs. The questionnaires were also translated into three languages: English, French, and Spanish. E-mails, follow-up letters, and phone calls were utilized to encourage participants to complete the questionnaires. Twenty-eight participants completed and returned the questionnaire which translates into a response rate of twenty-eight percent. Although this is a lower response rate than expected, the twenty-eight respondents were highly representative of the total population of the participants who had attended various water reform programs conducted by EDIEN since 1993.
The two primary goals of the evaluation were to assess the program's overall accomplishments since its inception in 1993 and to provide suggestions for future improvements. To help accomplish the evaluation objectives, the questionnaire addressed five areas: 1) Background information on the respondents and their functions within their countries; 2) Respondents' ratings of the seminars they attended; 3) Respondents' perception of how the situation had changed in their country since the EDI activity they attended was held; 4) The current situation for water policy reforms in the respondent's country; 5) Respondents' understanding of the role of EDI and The World Bank in water policy reform throughout the world. These were the primary evaluation findings:
· Positive impacts were reported by many of the respondents. Forty-one percent of the respondents said that reforms in the area of water management policies had been initiated as a result of the activity they had attended. Forty-six percent stated their countries had either developed or revised new water laws and tariffs or new policies for water management in their countries.
· Fifty-nine percent of the respondents were satisfied with the quality of their country's decision-making on water policies. The specific reasons for this apparent satisfaction are not known. However, sixty-three percent of the respondents stated that the quality of decision- making on water sector reform had improved since they attended the activity.
· As a result of the WPRP there was also the perception of noticeable changes in attitudes of the respondents. When asked to suggest specific training programs necessary to implement effective and sustainable water management reforms in their countries, thirty-two percent of  the respondents recommended training national staff and NGOs on pertinent issues of water policy reform. Forty-five percent suggested that EDI should conduct additional case studies and hold more workshops to help participant countries implement effective and sustainable water management reform.
· The respondents also offered specific recommendations to improve the courses offered in the WPRP. The four top priority impacts which respondents recommended EDI should be aiming towards were: increasing implementation of sound policies for better management of the country's water resources (twenty percent); development of environmentally sustainable water and improved dialogue between stakeholders (both fourteen percent); and the need for privatization of water management for their countries (thirteen percent). As indicated by the respondents, the two top priority content areas that EDI should emphasize in the future for water management are strengthening national institutions (twenty-three percent), and increasing national capacity for training of sector specialists (seventeen percent).
· Fifty-five percent of the respondents stated that learning about the experiences of other countries was the most useful aspect of the seminars for them. Correspondingly, twenty-five percent indicated that country presentations (i.e., presentations concerning their own country) were the least useful aspect.
· Based on their experiences, the respondents cited that EDI programs on Water Policy need to be less focused on theory and more focused on concrete recommendations, seminars, case study discussions, field visits, and new technologies. Clearly, more "hands-on" and "in- person" experiences and better case study discussions seem to be warranted. The most frequent responses revealed that fifty-nine percent of the respondents believed that WPRP should be "more focused" on concrete recommendations, while twenty-six percent said that it needed to be "much more focused" on concrete recommendations. Fifty-six percent of the respondents stated that the program needs to be "more focused" on seminars, while nineteen percent said they needed to be "much more focused" on seminars. Fifty-two percent of the respondents noted that the case study discussions would help to make the program "more focused," while thirty percent said that case studies could help make it "much more focused." Forty-four percent of the respondents stated that WPRP should be "less focused" on theory, while thirty-seven percent were neutral saying it needed to be "not more, not less focused" on theory. In sum, WPRP needs to focus more on concrete recommendations, seminars, and case study discussions and less on theory.
· The respondents rated the importance EDI had given to participants' involvement and the management and organization of the activities (fifty-nine percent of the participants rated both of these features as "very good") as the two best features of the seminars. However, a few respondents also gave a low rating to the importance given to participants' involvement (while fifty-nine percent rated this as "very good," another fifteen percent rated it only as "fair"). Some respondents were not satisfied with the duration of the activities (nineteen percent said this was "fair" while four percent rated it as "poor").
· Respondents reported high satisfaction levels for the courses they attended. Sixty-one percent were satisfied with the seminar they had attended, while thirty-six percent were completely satisfied. Only one respondent (three percent) was neither satisfied nor dissatisfied.
